ticket.title: Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)
ticket.original-body:
The models: @@@ ruby class Package < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :deliveries, :select=>'id, user, delivered, package_id' end
class Delivery < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :package end @@@
The find: @@@ ruby Package.find :all, :include=>:deliveries, :order=>'deliveries.delivered desc', :limit=>10 @@@
The 1st query: @@@ sql SELECT DISTINCT `packages`.id FROM `packages` LEFT OUTER JOIN `deliveries` ON deliveries.package_id = packages.id ORDER BY deliveries.delivered desc LIMIT 10 @@@
Because DISTINCT is being used with a non-selected order by column, records aren't returned in the desired order, so the 2nd AR query:
@@@ sql select deliveries.* where deliveries.package_id in ( ... ) @@@
returns the wrong rows. Wrong meaning X.delivered > Y.delivered yet X is not in the result set.
MySQL doesn't impose the "order by columns are required in select if DISTINCT is used". I wonder how this query would be generated on say MSSQL.
ticket.latest-body:
The models: @@@ ruby class Package < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :deliveries, :select=>'id, user, delivered, package_id' end
class Delivery < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :package end @@@
The find: @@@ ruby Package.find :all, :include=>:deliveries, :order=>'deliveries.delivered desc', :limit=>10 @@@
The 1st query: @@@ sql SELECT DISTINCT `packages`.id FROM `packages` LEFT OUTER JOIN `deliveries` ON deliveries.package_id = packages.id ORDER BY deliveries.delivered desc LIMIT 10 @@@
Because DISTINCT is being used with a non-selected order by column, records aren't returned in the desired order, so the 2nd AR query:
@@@ sql select deliveries.* where deliveries.package_id in ( ... ) @@@
returns the wrong rows. Wrong meaning X.delivered > Y.delivered yet X is not in the result set.
MySQL doesn't impose the "order by columns are required in select if DISTINCT is used". I wonder how this query would be generated on say MSSQL.
ticket.original-body-html:
The models:


class Package < ActiveRecord::Base
 has_many :deliveries,
          :select=>'id, user, delivered, package_id'
end

class Delivery < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :package
end

The find:


 Package.find :all, :include=>:deliveries, :order=>'deliveries.delivered desc', :limit=>10

The 1st query:


SELECT DISTINCT `packages`.id FROM `packages` LEFT OUTER JOIN `deliveries` ON deliveries.package_id = packages.id ORDER BY deliveries.delivered desc LIMIT 10

Because DISTINCT is being used with a non-selected order by column, records aren't returned in the desired order, so the 2nd AR query:


select deliveries.* where deliveries.package_id in ( ... )

returns the wrong rows. Wrong meaning X.delivered > Y.delivered yet X is not in the result set.

MySQL doesn't impose the "order by columns are required in select if DISTINCT is used". I wonder how this query would be generated on say MSSQL.

MySQL doesn't impose the "order by columns are required in select if DISTINCT is used". I wonder how this query would be generated on say MSSQL.

The models:


class Package < ActiveRecord::Base
 has_many :deliveries,
          :select=>'id, user, delivered, package_id'
end

class Delivery < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :package
end

The find:


 Package.find :all, :include=>:deliveries, :order=>'deliveries.delivered desc', :limit=>10

The 1st query:


SELECT DISTINCT `packages`.id FROM `packages` LEFT OUTER JOIN `deliveries` ON deliveries.package_id = packages.id ORDER BY deliveries.delivered desc LIMIT 10

Because DISTINCT is being used with a non-selected order by column, records aren't returned in the desired order, so the 2nd AR query:


select deliveries.* where deliveries.package_id in ( ... )

returns the wrong rows. Wrong meaning X.delivered > Y.delivered yet X is not in the result set.

MySQL doesn't impose the "order by columns are required in select if DISTINCT is used". I wonder how this query would be generated on say MSSQL.
version.title: Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)
Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)

version.body:
Tested on 2-3-stable:
@@@ ruby
def test_eager_association_loading_with_belongs_to_and_limit_non_selected_order_by comments = Comment.find(:all, :include => :post, :limit => 5, :order => 'comments.post_id') puts comments.inspect assert_equal 5, comments.length assert_equal [1,2,3,5,6], comments.collect { |c| c.id } end
@@@
got:
* SELECT * FROM "comments" ORDER BY comments.post_id LIMIT 5; * SELECT * FROM "posts" WHERE ("posts"."id" IN (1,2,4));
version.body-html:
Tested on 2-3-stable:


def test_eager_association_loading_with_belongs_to_and_limit_non_selected_order_by
  comments = Comment.find(:all, :include => :post, :limit => 5, :order => 'comments.post_id')
  puts comments.inspect
  assert_equal 5, comments.length
  assert_equal [1,2,3,5,6], comments.collect { |c| c.id }
end

got:

  • SELECT * FROM "comments" ORDER BY comments.post_id LIMIT 5;
  • SELECT * FROM "posts" WHERE ("posts"."id" IN (1,2,4));
version.title: Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)

version.body:
**Verified**
I was able to test this using following scenario:
@@@ ruby
class A < ActiveRecord::Base has_many :bs, :select => 'id, position, a_id' end
class B < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :a end
@@@
Data in Table 'as': +----+------+ | id | name | +----+------+ | 1 | A1 | | 2 | A2 | | 3 | A3 | +----+------+
Data in Table 'bs': +----+------+----------+ | id | a_id | position | +----+------+----------+ | 1 | 1 | 1 | | 2 | 1 | 4 | | 3 | 2 | 6 | | 4 | 2 | 2 | | 5 | 2 | 5 | | 6 | 3 | 3 | +----+------+----------+
Finding without :limit option yields:
@@@ ruby >> A.find :all, :include => :bs, :order => 'bs.position desc' => [#<A id: 2 ... >, #<A id: 1 ... >, #<A id: 3 ... >] @@@ (looks correct)
However, finding with :limit gives:
@@@ ruby >> A.find :all, :include => :bs, :order => 'bs.position desc', :limit => 2 => [#<A id: 2 ... >, #<A id: 3 ... >] @@@
Instead, it should give @@@ ruby [#<A id: 2 ... >, #<A id: 1 ... >] @@@
version.body-html:
Verified

I was able to test this using following scenario:


  class A < ActiveRecord::Base
    has_many :bs, :select => 'id, position, a_id'
  end

  class B < ActiveRecord::Base
    belongs_to :a
  end

Data in Table 'as':
+----+------+ | id | name | +----+------+ | 1 | A1 | | 2 | A2 | | 3 | A3 | +----+------+

Data in Table 'bs':
+----+------+----------+ | id | a_id | position | +----+------+----------+ | 1 | 1 | 1 | | 2 | 1 | 4 | | 3 | 2 | 6 | | 4 | 2 | 2 | | 5 | 2 | 5 | | 6 | 3 | 3 | +----+------+----------+

Finding without :limit option yields:

  >> A.find :all, :include => :bs, :order => 'bs.position desc'
  => [#<A id: 2 ... >, #<A id: 1 ... >, #<A id: 3 ... >]

(looks correct)

However, finding with :limit gives:

  >> A.find :all, :include => :bs, :order => 'bs.position desc', :limit => 2
  => [#<A id: 2 ... >, #<A id: 3 ... >]

Instead, it should give

  [#<A id: 2 ... >, #<A id: 1 ... >]
version.title: Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)
Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)

version.body: Ok, I had that backwards. I've attached a corrected patch that fails on Mysql & Sqlite3. It passes on PostgresSQL.
version.body-html: Ok, I had that backwards. I've attached a corrected patch that fails on Mysql & Sqlite3. It passes on PostgresSQL.

version.title: Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)

version.body:
Verified, +1
The preivious patch does not apply anymore. The attached one applies cleanly on master and demonstrates the bug
version.body-html:
Verified, +1

The preivious patch does not apply anymore. The attached one applies cleanly on master and demonstrates the bug
version.title: Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)

version.body:
-1
I don't believe that :limit or :select are really the problem here.
Unlike Postgres, MySQL orders null values first by default (ASC). So, in the Post has_many Comments example: @@@ ruby Post.find(:all, :include => :comments, :order => 'comments.post_id asc') @@@ Because we're ordering by the foreign key, Posts without Comments are before those with Comments.
When limiting the Posts returned in the find() above to n, you get the first n records (as expected), nulls first in MySQL.
I've attached a patch to help illustrate.
version.body-html:
-1

I don't believe that :limit or :select are really the problem here.

Unlike Postgres, MySQL orders null values first by default (ASC). So, in the Post has_many Comments example:

Post.find(:all, :include => :comments, :order => 'comments.post_id asc')
Because we're ordering by the foreign key, Posts without Comments are before those with Comments.

When limiting the Posts returned in the find() above to n, you get the first n records (as expected), nulls first in MySQL.

I've attached a patch to help illustrate.
version.title: Eager Loading With :limit Returns Wrong Result Set (MySQL)
